content: Having both accounts is no problem. On copying the messages, you could highlight the folder and click 'copy to' if only a few messages. If many, I recommend creating a filter to copy (not move) the messages. When done, spot check that the messages are intact. The challenge is that IMAP was not designed for a large number of uploads.

content: My guess is the folder is threaded. Highlight the folder with the messages, then click view>sort by and tick 'unthreaded.' If the menu bar isn't visible, click the alt key first.
creator: davidsk

content: Highlight a unified folder, right-click and select 'properties' and then click 'choose' and then tick or untick the folders you want to appear.
creator: davidsk

content: File/New/Saved Search... (press Alt if the Menu Bar is hidden) and add any set of folders to the search. This doesn't require the Unified view.
creator: sfhowes

content: That is because you set up the account on new PC as POP. if you delete the POP account and reinstall as IMAP, you will be able to do as that link indicates. BUT, if your desire is to download permanently to PC to keep, then you would need to then create Local Folders folders and copy the messages to the local folders folder to keep. My inference is that you may not want to keep the old account and you emphasized downloading to your PC.

content:
That doesn't seem normal, as the release version does not autoupdate to the beta version. Assuming you are on windows, Try: 

   Exit Thunderbird if running.    click windows key and 'r' key    Enter: thunderbird.exe -P --allow-downgrade    click on 'OK'

However, I am not clear on what change you are anticipating to revert, as those two versions have same basic layout.

content: I believe the import-export addon can do this. Create a folder in Local Folders, highlight and rightclick and select import-export and click to import mbox. Another approach is to exit thunderbird, copy the inbox message file to Mail\Local Folders folder and restart thunderbird.

content: This may be a security app from the email provider. I don't know from whom you received the message. The sender may have more information on this, as this PSM is not part of Thunderbird.
creator: davidsk

content: My guess, having no details, is that the two accounts are using the same SMTP server. You can check that by verifying first that there are two SMTP servers defined and that each account uses the right one. If this is the situation, I encourage setting the Description field for each SMTP server to be unique so that it is easy to verify on the account setting pane.
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks David, I checked that one and I have an own smtp setting for every mailbox. That was not the cause. But I found the missing mail. It was hidden in the outbox of the local folder. Unfortunately this folder was not shown by default and I wasn't able to make it visible. I used a work around by modifying a grouped folder showing also the content of the outbox of the local folder. And there it was, the missing mail which Thunderbird tried unsuccessfully to send. I was able to delete the mail now and the issue is gone.
creator: marko.b

content:
When did email become a social media look alike. What a poor design choice. Oh well, I really have no knowledge here, but a little googling lead me to https://office365itpros.com/2023/09/19/outlook-reactions-disable/ which offer a tidbit about a custom header. The x-ms-reactions: disallow message header This venerable article http://kb.mozillazine.org/Custom_headers provides instructions that allow using the config editor a add a custom header to all outgoing email. So you can simply add the header item to prevent reactions in reply.

Probably not what is needed here. Although there are ways to include it in your outgoing mail to force it off in your mail, but there may be other headers that can be filtered on to get them out of the way.

What does a typical reaction have in the header of the message (ctrl+U) opens the message source
